article-meta.aff: Department of Pediatrics, Division of Child Neurology, Arkansas Children’s Hospital, Little Rock, AR, USA

author-notes.corresp: Richard E. Frye, MD, PhD, Department of Pediatrics, Division of Child Neurology, Arkansas Children’s Hospital Research Institute, Slot 512-41B, 13 Children's Way, Little Rock, AR 72202 Email: REFrye@uams.edu

abstract.p: Both copy number changes in the 22q13 region and mitochondrial disease have been associated with autism spectrum disorder. In this report, for the first time, a girl with autism spectrum disorder is described who exhibits both mitochondrial disease and a 22q13.1-33 duplication. This child demonstrated hypotonia, developmental delays, growth deficiency, microcephaly, dysmorphic facial features, and white matter abnormalities, consistent with previous cases of 22q13 region duplication. The patient also demonstrated a unique pattern of electron transport chain abnormalities with marked decreases in complex II and II/III in fibroblasts and complex I/III and II/III in muscle tissue. The 22q13.1-33 region contains 6 genes associated with mitochondrial function. Thus, disruption of this chromosomal region could cause many of the clinical findings in this child through disruption of mitochondrial function. Therefore, a mitochondrial workup should be considered in individuals with copy number changes within the 22q13 region, such as those with Phelan–McDermid syndrome.

body.p:
The autism spectrum disorders are a heterogeneous group of neurodevelopmental disorders characterized by impairments in communication and social interaction along with restrictive and repetitive behaviors. 1 Many of the cognitive and behavioral features of the autism spectrum disorders are believed to arise from central nervous system dysfunction, but non-central nervous system abnormalities have been associated with autism spectrum disorder. 2,3 Recent studies have implicated dysfunction of physiological systems aside from the central nervous system in individuals with autism spectrum disorder. Indeed, dysfunction of the immune, detoxification, redox regulation/oxidative stress, and energy generation systems has been described. 2
–5 This suggests that the underlying abnormality, in at least some children with autism spectrum disorder, may arise from systemic, rather than central nervous system specific, dysfunction. 4,5 This has expanded the view of the possible etiological mechanisms causing autism spectrum disorders and can help explain the non–central nervous system abnormalities seen in some children with autism spectrum disorder. 2
–5

Recently, mitochondrial dysfunction has been proposed to explain the connection between the diverse medical symptoms associated with autism spectrum disorders. 2 A recent meta-analysis found that, in previous studies, about 5% of children with autism spectrum disorder met criteria for mitochondrial disease, while as many as 30% of children with autism spectrum disorder manifested biomarkers of mitochondrial dysfunction. 3 This meta-analysis found that only 23% of the children diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder and mitochondrial disease have a known abnormality in mitochondria deoxyribonucleic acid. 3 Although abnormalities in nuclear genes can also cause mitochondrial dysfunction, nuclear genes abnormalities have been rarely reported in children with autism spectrum disorder and mitochondrial disease. 3 In fact, in a review of 112 published cases of children diagnosed with both mitochondrial disease and autism spectrum disorder, only 1 case implicated a nuclear gene, the SCO2 gene, 6 a gene which controls cytochrome c oxidase assembly. 7 Mutations in SCO2 have been otherwise linked to fatal infantile cardioencephalomyopathy 7
–10 and spontaneous abortion. 9

In the current report, we present a case of a child with autism spectrum disorder and mitochondrial disease who manifests duplication in 22q13.1-22q13.33, a chromosomal region that includes the SCO2 gene. Only 1 other chromosomal duplication has been linked to mitochondrial disease and autism spectrum disorder, an inverted duplication in 15q11-13 in 2 children. 11 This report adds to the understanding of the connection between autism spectrum disorder and mitochondrial disease and helps broaden the understanding of the pathophysiology associated with chromosomal duplications.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: The patient was born to a 27-year-old G2P1-2 woman through a gestation complicated by oligohydramnios and diet-controlled gestational diabetes. She was born preterm at 34 weeks’ gestation with an unremarkable neonatal course. Development was normal until 5 months old when cyanotic episodes, later diagnosed as Sandifer syndrome, began. Development was globally delayed—she did not crawl until 21 months, she did not walk until 30 months, and she did not say “Mama” until 3 years of age. At 3 years of age, she was diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder. She had a past medical history of hip dysplasia, eczema, and a tonsillectomy and adenoidectomy.

At 4 years of age, the patient suffered from a 10-minute generalized tonic–clonic seizure. She was referred to our clinic for further evaluation. The Denver Developmental Scale II demonstrated social milestones at 2 years of age, fine motor milestones at 15 months of age, language milestones at 1 year of age, and gross motor milestones at 3 years of age. Family history was significant for early dementia and bipolar disorder on the parental side of the family and multiple miscarriages in the mother and the maternal grandmother. Four siblings had no neurodevelopmental problems.

Physical examination demonstrated symmetric growth retardation. Head circumference was 46 cm (<1%ile), weight was 13 kg (<1%), and height was 91.5 cm (<1%). Skin examination demonstrated a maculopapular rash on the back and fine capillary hemangiomas on her cheeks. Dysmorphology included small forehead, low-set small ears, small eyes, and midface hypoplasia.

The patient was nonverbal but unusually friendly. She spontaneously approached the examiner, made eye contact, and tried to pull the examiner out the door with her. She had frequent repetitive movements—she repetitively ran into the center of the examining room and rocked back and forth. The patient met criteria for the diagnosis of autistic disorder per Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, fourth edition, criteria. 1 The autism diagnostic observation schedule examination further confirmed the diagnosis of autistic disorder. 12

A 23-hour electroencephalogram demonstrated frequent moderate-to-high-amplitude focal sharp waves, spikes, and spike-and-wave discharges arising from the right centrotemporal region, at times independently, but usually synchronously with additional spikes and spike-and-wave discharges arising from the left centrotemporal region. Discharges were more frequent on the right compared with the left. Discharges were most prominent during drowsiness and sleep when they occurred in semirhythmic runs at 1 to 2 Hz. Intermittent focal right posterior temporal and posterior quadrant slowing in the delta and theta range was also seen. There were occasional runs of bifrontal beta and delta activity.

Metabolic workup demonstrated an elevation in lactate (3.9 [0.5–2.2] mg/dL); pyruvate (0.166 [0.030–0.107] mmol/L); creatine kinase (202 U/L [30–200]); serum alanine-to-lysine ratio (2.6 [<2.5]); short-, medium-, and long-chain acyl-carnitines (C6 0.43 [≤0.12] μmol/L, C8 0.4 [≤0.23] μmol/L, C10 0.88 [≤0.35] μmol/L, C10:1 0.48 [≤0.41] μmol/L, C12 0.19 [≤0.12] μmol/L, C14 0.15 [≤0.07] μmol/L, C14:1 0.58 [≤0.23] μmol/L, C14:2 0.13 [≤0.12] μmol/L, C16 0.36 [≤0.10] μmol/L, C16:1 0.08 [≤0.05] μmol/L, C18 0.10 [≤0.05] μmol/L, C18:1 0.56 [≤0.16] μmol/L, C18:2 0.13 [≤0.08] μmol/L); and urine organic acids (succinic 57.7 [≤51] mmol/mol creatinine, fumaric 4.5 [≤2.2] mmol/mol creatinine, and malic 4.7 [≤2.5] mmol/mol creatinine).

In light of the significant abnormal laboratory values, muscle and skin biopsies were performed. Light microscopy demonstrated mild myofiber size irregularity, fibers with increased sarcoplasmic lipid and succinate dehydrogenase–hyperreactive (“ragged-blue”) fibers (see Figure 1A, B). Electron microscopy demonstrated rare subsarcolemmal myelin figures, an increased number of subsarcolemmal mitochondria with mild irregularities of cristae, mitochondria undergoing degeneration and showing increased lipid-like deposits (see Figure 1C, D).

caption.p: Muscle biopsy from patient with 22q13 duplication. (A) Oil red “O” stain demonstrated an increase sarcoplasmic lipid. (B) Scattered succinate dehydrogenase–hyperreactive “ragged blue” fibers. (C) Electron microscopy demonstrated increased subsarcolemmal mitochondria. (D) Electron microscopy demonstrates increased lipid-like deposits

sec.p: Functional electron transport chain studies were conducted on the muscle tissue and fibroblasts derived from the skin (Baylor Medical Genetics Laboratory, Houston, Texas). 13 Electron transport chain results demonstrated different patterns in muscle tissue and fibroblasts. Uncorrected electron transport chain function in muscle tissue was depressed in all complexes except complex II with an elevation in citrate synthase indicating mitochondrial proliferation consistent with the electron microscopy findings (Figure 2A). In comparison, electron transport chain function in fibroblasts was overactive except for complex II and II/III with no change in citrate synthase, suggesting no compensatory mitochondrial proliferation (Figure 2D). Correcting for citrate synthase demonstrated a marked depression in complex function, especially in complex I/III and II/III of the muscle tissue (Figure 2B). Because of the conspicuous elevation in complex function in fibroblasts, electron transport chain function was normalized with respect to the complex with the maximum function (Figure 2C, F) since some case reports of mitochondrial dysfunction consider relative electron transport chain function when conspicuous increases in complex function are found. 14,15 With correction to the maximum activity, complex I/III and II/III function were found to be markedly decreased (<50% normalized activity) in muscle tissue and complex II and complex II/III were found to be markedly decreased in fibroblasts (Figure 2C, F). Fibroblasts derived from skin were incubated with D3-palmitate and l-carnitine in duplicate for 72 hours (Baylor Institute of Metabolic Disease, Dallas, Texas) 16 and demonstrated marked elevations in D3-C4, suggesting a short-chain fatty acid or an electron transport chain disorder (Figure 2G).

caption.p: Functional electron transport chain (ETC) studies for muscle tissue and fibroblasts. (A, D) Uncorrected electron transport chain function in muscle tissue and fibroblasts. In the muscle tissue, all complexes except complex II were depressed and citrate synthase was elevated. In fibroblasts, all complexes demonstrated overactivity except for complex II and II/III with no change in citrate synthase. (B, E) Electron transport chain function corrected for citrate synthase. In muscle tissue, electron transport chain complex function was considerably depressed. (C, F) Electron transport chain function normalized with respect to the complex with maximum activity. In muscle tissue, complex I/III and II/III were markedly depressed in function, while complex II and complex II/III were markedly depressed in fibroblasts. (G) Beta-oxidation studies of fibroblasts demonstrated marked elevations in short-chain fatty acids.

sec.p: Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain demonstrated nonspecific bilateral small focal areas of increased T2 and fluid attenuated inverse recovery signal in the occipital lobes most consistent with incomplete myelination (Figure 3A, B) and mild prominence of the right occipital and temporal horns (Figure 3C, D). Single voxel magnetic resonance spectroscopy of the bilateral deep gray matter and white matter was normal.

caption.p: Magnetic resonance fluid-attenuated inverse recovery images of the brain. (A, B) Subtle nonspecific small focal areas of increased signal were seen in the occipital lobes bilaterally, most consistent with incomplete myelination. (C, D) Mild prominence of the right occipital and temporal horns was also seen.

sec.p: GeneDx high-resolution oligonucleotide array (GeneDX v4, Gaithersburg, Maryland) demonstrated a 10.6-Mb duplication from 22q13.1-22q13.33 (40,561,491-51,186,190) that did not involve the minimum critical region for 22q13.3 deletion syndrome (SHANK3, ACR, and RABL2B genes) also known as Phelan–McDermid syndrome. Quantitative confirmation of the duplication was performed by polymerase chain reaction analysis of the FBLN1 gene in 22q13.31. Short-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase sequencing of exons 1-10 was found to be normal (GeneDx). 17 An oligonucleotide array comparative genomic hybridization analysis demonstrated no deletions or duplications in approximately 180 nuclear genes involved in mitochondrial function, including genes involved in fatty-acid oxidation, carnitine metabolism, mitochondrial deoxyribonucleic acid biogenesis, maintenance, transcription and translation, or electron transport chain complex assembly (MitoMet, Baylor Medical Genetics Laboratory) aside from the genes involved in the duplicated chromosomal region. Mitochondrial deoxyribonucleic acid sequencing, performed using standard laboratory methodology, was unremarkable (Baylor Medical Genetics Laboratory). 18 –20 Mitochondrial deoxyribonucleic acid content of the muscle was found to be elevated at 161% of normal. 21,22

A lumbar puncture demonstrated normal cerebrospinal fluid glucose (58 [45-80] mg/dL), protein (40 [15-45] mg/dL), red blood cell count (0 [0] cells/μL), and white cell count (0 [0-5] cells/μL). Cerebrospinal fluid pyruvate was normal (0.157 [0.06-0.190] mmol/L), but lactate was elevated (2.5 [0.6-2.2] mmol/L). Levels of neurotransmitter metabolites (homovanillic acid 622 [218-852] nmol/L, 5-hydroxy-indolacetic acid 285 [66-338] nmol/L, 3-O-methyldopa 39 [<100] nmol/L), neopterin (15 [7-20] nmol/L), tetrahydrobiopterin (33 [9-40] nmol/L) and 5-methyltetrahydrofolate (69 [40-128] nmol/L) were normal. Additional blood testing performed during the lumbar puncture confirmed elevated levels of lactic acid (5.0 [0.5-2.2] mmol/L) and pyruvate (0.182 [0.030-0.107] mmol/L) and high alanine-to-lysine ratio (3.8 [<2.5]). Serum neopterin was also found to be elevated (12.9 [2-10] nmol/L).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This report describes a girl with nonregressive autism spectrum disorder with both a 10.6-Mb duplication from 22q13.1 to 22q13.33 and a mitochondrial disease. Specifically, using the Morava et al criterion, 2,23 this patient demonstrated the maximum of 4 points in the clinical signs and symptoms portion of the criteria—developmental delay (1), seizures (1), gastrointestinal tract abnormalities (1), and growth abnormalities (1); the maximum of 4 points for the metabolic-imaging portion of the criteria—lactate (2), urinary tricarbon acid excretion (2), elevated cerebrospinal fluid lactate (2); and the maximum of 4 points for the muscle morphology portion of the criteria—abnormal mitochondria on electron microscopy (2) and ragged blue fibers (4). This patient’s findings provide a maximum total score for this criterion (12), which is consistent with a definite mitochondrial disease. Other findings that support a mitochondrial disease are elevations in pyruvate and acyl-carnitines, evidence of mitochondrial proliferation in the muscle, and the functional electron transport chain and beta-oxidation abnormalities.

No additional genetic defects were found in this patient to account for the mitochondrial disease aside from the 10.6-Mb chromosomal duplication. However, this duplicated chromosomal region contains several genes involved in mitochondrial function. The SCO2 gene controls cytochrome c oxidase assembly, 7 and mutations in this gene have been linked to fatal infantile cardioencephalomyopathy 7
–10 and spontaneous abortion. 9 The TYMP gene codes for a thymidine phosphorylase that balances deoxynucleotide pools, 24 and mutations in this gene cause mitochondrial deoxyribonucleic acid depletion syndrome–1, an autosomal recessive progressive multisystem disorder with onset between the second and fifth decades. 25 The CPT1B gene codes for muscle mitochondrial carnitine palmitoyltransferase, a protein that transports long-chain fatty acyl-CoA from the cytoplasm into the mitochondria for beta-oxidation. 26 Human disease has not been associated with the CPT1B gene, but homozygous deletions in mice have caused embryonic death, and heterozygous deletions in mice have caused increased fatality after cold-challenge. 27 The TRMU gene codes for a transfer ribonucleic acid 5-methlaminomethyl-2-thiouridylate methyltransferase that is essential for mitochondrial transfer ribonucleic acid modification. 28 The TRMU gene has been associated with aminoglycoside-induced and nonsyndromic deafness 29 and acute infantile liver failure. 30 The NDUFA6 gene codes for the nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide-ubiquinone oxidoreductase 1α subcomplex 6, one of the accessory subunits of electron transport chain complex I. 31 The ACO2 gene codes for mitochondrial aconitase, the second enzymes in the tricaboxylic acid cycle. Clearly, this chromosomal region has a concentration of mitochondrial nuclear genes, and abnormalities in this area (mutations and copy number variations) have the potential to cause mitochondrial disease.

Duplication in the 22q13 region has been reported in several cases with variations in the characteristics observed. Several cases have reported hypotonia, 32 developmental delay, 32 mental retardation, 33,34 autism spectrum disorder, 34 bipolar disorder, 33 growth deficiency, 32,35 retinitis pigmentosa, 36 microcephaly, 34,35 dysmorphic facial features, 33 –35 bilateral cleft lip and palate, 35 cryptorchidism with hypospadias, 35 hemivertebrae, 35 syndactyly, 33 complex heart defects, 35 and white matter and hippocampus abnormalities. 33 The patient described in this report demonstrated hypotonia, developmental delays, growth deficiency, microcephaly, autism spectrum disorder, dysmorphic facial features, and white matter abnormalities, like previously reported cases with duplications in this region. Of the features that the patient described in this report demonstrated, many of them, including hypotonia, developmental delays, growth deficiency, microcephaly, and white matter abnormalities, can be explained by mitochondrial disease. In addition, of the features reported in the previous 22q13 duplication cases, retinitis pigmentosa could be related to mitochondrial abnormalities, 37 and bipolar disorder has also been associated with mitochondrial dysfunction. 38

The identification of 2 pairs of recurrent proximal breakpoints on 22q13 suggests that this region may be prone to recombination. 36 This is echoed by the fact that both 22q13 microduplication 32 and 22q13 deletion syndromes 36,39 are recognized disorders. Unfortunately, previous case reports and case series have not investigated mitochondrial abnormalities as part of the workup for the etiology for the clinical findings in cases with copy number changes in the 22q13 region. For example, although clinical manifestation of Phelan–McDermid syndrome are believed to be due to a deletion of the SHANK3 gene, chromosomal deletions in individuals with this syndrome not uncommonly include flanking regions of the SHANK3 gene within the 22q13 region. 40 Given that the 22q13 region has a particularly high concentration of mitochondrial genes, investigation (or at least screening) of mitochondrial disease in individuals with genetic disturbances within this region may help better define the pathologic mechanisms of clinical findings that are attributable to abnormalities in the 22q13 region and help improve the understanding of the connection between mitochondrial disease and neurodevelopmental disorders.

fn.label: Author's Note
fn.p: This study has not been presented or published previously.

fn.label: Declaration of Conflicting Interests
fn.p: The author declared the following potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article: In the past, Dr Frye has provided expert opinion for child neurology cases for both the plaintiff and defendant, including cases with children suffering from mitochondrial disorders. All proceeds from such work were provided to the Department of Pediatrics at the University of Texas, with some of these funds supporting Dr Frye’s research.
